Line 18: Line 18:
===Beginnings===
===Beginnings===
[[Image:Google.com front page.png|thumb|right|300px|Google.com front page]]
[[Image:Google.com front page.png|thumb|right|300px|Google.com front page]]
â  
Google began as a research project in January [[1996]] <sup>[http://www.google.com/intl/en/corporate/history.html]</sup> by [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]], two [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students at [[Stanford University|Stanford]]. They developed the hypothesis that a search engine based on analysis of the relationships between Web sites would produce improved results over the basic techniques then in use. It was originally nicknamed ''BackRub'' because the system checked [[backlinks]] to estimate a site's importance. (A small search engine called [[RankDex]] was already exploring a similar strategy.)
Google began as a research project in January [[1996]] <sup>[http://www.google.com/intl/en/corporate/history.html]</sup> by [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]], two [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students at [[Stanford University|Stanford]]. They developed the hypothesis that a search engine based on analysis of the relationships between Web sites would produce improved results over the basic techniques then in use. It was originally nicknamed ''BackRub'' because the system checked [[backlinks]] to estimate a site's importance. (A small search engine called [[RankDex]] was already exploring a similar strategy.)
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant Web pages must be the most relevant pages associated with the search, Page and Brin tested their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. Originally the search engine used the [[Stanford University|Stanford]] website with the domain ''google.stanford.edu'' (see the [http://www.archive.org/web/web.php Internet Archive Wayback Machine] search for [http://web.archive.org/web/*/http://google.stanford.edu http://google.stanford.edu]). The domain ''www.google.com'' was registered on [[September 15]], [[1997]]. They formally incorporated their company, ''Google, Inc.'', on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant Web pages must be the most relevant pages associated with the search, Page and Brin tested their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. Originally the search engine used the [[Stanford University|Stanford]] website with the domain ''google.stanford.edu'' (see the [http://www.archive.org/web/web.php Internet Archive Wayback Machine] search for [http://web.archive.org/web/*/http://google.stanford.edu http://google.stanford.edu]). The domain ''www.google.com'' was registered on [[September 15]], [[1997]]. They formally incorporated their company, ''Google, Inc.'', on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].
Line 38: Line 37:
Analysts speculate that Google's response to Yahoo! will be to continue to make technical and visual enhancements to personalized searches, using the personal data that is gathering from [[Orkut]], [[Gmail]], and [[Froogle]] to produce unique results based on the user. Frequently, new Google enhancements or products appear in its inventory. Products and [[demo]]s [http://labs.google.com/ Google Labs], the experimental section of Google.com help Google maximize its relationships with its users by including them in the beta development, design and testing stages of new products and enhancements of already existing ones.
Analysts speculate that Google's response to Yahoo! will be to continue to make technical and visual enhancements to personalized searches, using the personal data that is gathering from [[Orkut]], [[Gmail]], and [[Froogle]] to produce unique results based on the user. Frequently, new Google enhancements or products appear in its inventory. Products and [[demo]]s [http://labs.google.com/ Google Labs], the experimental section of Google.com help Google maximize its relationships with its users by including them in the beta development, design and testing stages of new products and enhancements of already existing ones.
â   â
====Original Hardware====
  â   â
The [http://web.archive.org/web/19990209043945/google.stanford.edu/googlehardware.html original hardware] used by Google included:
  â   â
*Sun Ultra II with dual 200MHz processors, and 256MB of [[RAM]]. This was the main machine for the original Backrub system.
  â   â
*2 x 300 MHz Dual [[Pentium]] II Servers donated by [[Intel]], they included 512MB of RAM and 9 x 9GB hard drives between the two. It was on these that the main search ran.
  â   â
*F50 IBM RS6000 donated by [[IBM]], included 4 processors, 512MB of memory and 8 x 9GB hard drives.
  â   â
*Two additional boxes included 3 x 9GB hard drives and 6 x 4GB hard drives respectively. (the original storage for Backrub). These were attached to the Sun Ultra II.
  â   â
*IBM disk expansion box with another 8 x 9GB hard drives donated by IBM.
  â   â
*Homemade disk box which contained 10 x 9GB [[SCSI]] hard drives
  â   â
====Logo Evolutions====
  â   â
The [http://www.google.com/intl/en/stickers.html Google logo] has changed dramatically over the years. The following are the official Google logos.
  â
<gallery>
  â
Image:googlelogo_5.jpg|<center>Late 1996
  â
Image:googlelogo_6.jpg|<center>1998 - July 1999
  â
Image:googlelogo_current.gif|<center>July 1999 - Present
  â
</gallery>
  â   â
Google is also known for its innovative holiday logos, [http://www.google.com/holidaylogos.html see their logo archive]. A website has been created that relives these imaginative logos by displaying them randomly on every page-load: [http://google.abrahamjoffe.com.au/ Holiday Google].
